titleStmt.title: IG VII 115-117 Megara, IVth-Vth century AD. Three epigrams on a sarcophagus

div.head: α. 115
α. 2543
div.l: He gave the most gentle and kind man to all his comrades.
He gave trust to good men, hostility to evil.
He gave his exultation to myriad judgments in the city --
Good judgments to both citizens and foreigners.
Fate seized his body and dragged it underground,
But his heart was hoisted to the skies.
Know all this, such was the life of Nikokrates.

div.head: β. 116
div.l: Klotho the weaver took Nikokrates from life
After his twenty hard-labored years were done.
Famous for his skill, Nikokrates from the blood of priests,
Nikokrates, the son of his father Kallituchos.

div.head: γ. 117
div.l: The body of Nikokrates was buried under the hallowed earth,
His heart was swiftly carred up into the divine ether.
Greetings to you, Pluto, the innocent god, on account of fate.
He remains gentle and delightful, made all especially glorious
The son of Kallituchos ... another light
Before the loathsome ... to te immortals ...
